Top quality tutorial. In my experience the place where most errors occur is the calculation of the parallel resistances. Students make errors on the calculator entering all the numbers. I now teach product over sum which has a far greater success rate. For anyone who does not know  two resistors in parallel can be calculated by multiplying the two values together and then dividing by the sum of their values. So lets say 2 resistors     4 ohms & 6 ohms.    (4 x 6) divided by (4 +6) = 24 divided by 10 =2.4 ohms. For 3 resistor just calculate an equivalent value for the first 2 and do the calculation again with the first answer and the third resistor. There seem to be far less calculator input errors using this method.
May you live a thousand years

I've gone through physics and MCAT prep thinking series vs parallel was about perpendicularity not about one vs multiple paths the current can take. He says it in the plainest way to mitigate any confusion. THANK YOU
ANSWERS: 1. 30 ohms 2. 5 ohms 3. 24/13 ohms = 1.8461 ohms 4. 25 ohms 5. 60 ohms 6. 15 ohms 7. 60 ohms 8. 100 ohms

About the resistors in parallel... You basically want to convert the resistance into conductance, add them together and again convert the sum to resistance. You convert the two by flipping the fraction. 10 can be expressed as 10 over 1. So by flipping it you get 1 over 10.  Hope makes sense

A question, imagine there is a main path/wire connected to battery. Now that main wire has 2 resistors. Now I put a zero resistor wire (Let's assume its zero or close to zero). One side of the wire is in between that 2 resistor and the other one is connected to the main wire.  How will the current flow?

At 15:22, I remember having problems like this in my electronics classes.  But who in the HELL designs a circuit like this?  It’s preposterous, just a way to trip up students on a test.  Yeah, I understand it’s an exercise in rearranging and combining things down but still, it’s just idiotic to come up with circuits like this.  Much the same as the so-called practical examples I remember in basic algebra word problems.  The problem was something like how much grass seed would it take to cover area X exactly, answer is something stupid like 4.3 ounces.  Well where in the world are you gonna buy 4.3 ounces of grass seed when it’s only sold by the pound?  If you’re gonna give me “practical” examples, do it in real world terms.  No engineer in his right mind is going to design a monstrosity of a circuit like this given constraints on parts counts and economy.  OK I’ll shut up now.

I found the answer i was doing the last part wrong for the math
You first add them all then raise them to the negative one power

U can compare the current like a stream of water   When in series it only goes on one path   So the req is the greatest values  When it’s in series the current then proceeds to venture on different path while mostly going on a path that has less resistance.   Since it’s parallel, the current is divided so that’s why the req will be the smallest value in a parallel circuit

8:32 in series
7:32 Fucc, you're turning into some math game....

some calculator's have a fraction button. or you can find a common denominator. so basically. if you do it by finding the common denominator you would see that 24 is the common denominator as that's the lowest number that all 3 of those numbers (4,6,8) can go into the same number. so you would then times the number of times it takes that number to go into 24 so basically you would do 1/4x6/6, 1/6x4/4, 1/8x3/3) which would give you 6/24, 4/24, 3/24 then you add them while keeping the common denominator the same so you would then have 13/24.. now simply divide. and that gets you 1.846...
you can still put the numbers in just as they are but use brackets so that the program's bodmas doesn't interfere

nope they are not in series

Sum of inverses gives you the ability to take lowest common denominator so generally that is the formula used for parallel combination. But of course, while calculating, you can just use what you have stated. However it's easier to take lowest denominator while solving by hand.

Im pretty sure voltage is always the same across the circuit. However, the current is not always constant around the circuit, because V = I*R, and V = I2 * R2. Maybe youre getting voltage and current confused? I might be wrong tho

i use Req to solve combination circuits by solving series/parallel circuits until it has only one loop left, which i then use it to calculate Rt=(R1+R2+R3...). and yeah voltage will drop across any path with resistors in it. voltage is the same everywhere in circuit = total voltage - sum of voltage drop across resistors = 0 which is basically what KVL stated.
